utterances: As I was growing up and studying music and learning all wonderful things about it, what I discovered was that my students really didn't have a background in the classical setting.
And what I tried to do as I was teaching was to teach them great music and show it to them and then bring them out of it and say, okay, this is what was done.
Where are you going from this point on?
And I had some success with that.
So you would say, this is what has been done in terms of musicians like or composers like Mozart or Beethoven, like that?
Oh yes, and also performers who did things like Paganini and so forth.
Look at this guy, who was a little kid, who became one of the greatest violinists in the history of (unintelligible).
Can't you do that yourself?
You can.
And did you also perform with them?
Oh, yeah, I'm a jazz trombone player from age eight on, and I'm 75 now, so, you know...
So you were playing them Jack Teagarden and that sort of thing, too.
Oh gosh yes, that and Tommy Dorsey, imitated them all.
That's nice.
So Victor, does that accord with your experience?
Absolutely, because that's how I learned.
I had, you know, great elders, you could say, even though they were my brothers who were just a little older than me.
So they were my elders who were playing along with me, and they were turning me on to their elders.
So they were turning me on to people like, you know, Coltrane and Bird and then the great bass players, you know.
And it's been world better for me since then, you know.
Like, I don't play just like one particular bass player.
I play like me.
And I just use bits and pieces that I enjoy and that I like from all the other bass players that I listen to.
So, through them, I was doing exactly what this teacher was doing.
Even though, you know, my teaching was being done in my household.
I think, you know, I think what's he's saying is exactly the right format.
You expose the kids to a lot, and then you play it with them so that they have an opportunity of reproducing what they've been shown.

Is there a moment, and I wanted to ask you, too, Doug, is there a moment when you're playing with somebody in a group and then you can look them in the eye and engage them in one of those little exchanges of riffs back and forth, a magical moment where you can start saying: You can play, too.
Oh, yes.
I did that with Big Jay McNeeley(ph), one of our great honking saxophone players.
We did fours in ""Bye Bye Birdie,"" and we had a wonderful time.
Nice, nice.
The one thing you have to do with kids is allow them to be wrong.
In other words, as a teacher, I'm not saying you have to improvise this way, you have to do it that way.
No, just let them do it.
Let them feel what music, expressing music is like.
And then over the time, we'll, you know, we'll fit them into our box a little bit more.
But first, let them just freely express.
Who knows, they might create a whole new box.
Doug, thanks very much for the call, appreciate it.
You're welcome, thank you.
I wondered if we could get a little bit of instruction ourselves.
Can I ask you first about the instrument you're playing?
It looks like a conventional bass, with frets and everything, but it's a solid-body guitar that's made of is it two pieces of wood?
It looks like the yin-yang symbol.
Exactly.
It's a yin-yang symbol on the front, and it is two pieces of wood.
It's a piece of ebony, and this is yellow wood from South America somewhere.
I'm not sure of the name of it.

But it's a pretty standard guitar, made by Fodera in Brooklyn, New York, and, you know, people think it's well, it is specially made for me, but it's a standard bass anyone can get, four-string, fretted bass, pretty regular.
And the sound we think of the electric bass and, you know, we think of we think we know the sound.
You get different sounds out of that thing than we're accustomed to.
I do get different sounds, and that's from imitating my brothers and imitating all the different sounds throughout life that I've heard, not just musically but other sounds in life that I hear.
The same way we can attempt to imitate them with our voice, I attempt to imitate these sounds, animals and all sorts of things, with my guitar.
I've also been told by a bass player who's on our staff to ask you to demonstrate a couple of different techniques...
Sure.
For example, slapping.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah, that comes from a bass player.
Slapping, when I grew up, it was called thumping, invented by a great bass player who's still around named Larry Graham, who played with Sly Stone.
And I'll play a song of his using the technique.
But it's a technique where you hit the string with your thumb, and then I might pluck it with one of my index or middle fingers.
But the slapping sound, if I were to play a certain line with my normal fingers, normal technique...
(Soundbite of music)
That's the normal sound.
If I slap it, it's this.
(Soundbite of music)
Right, that's the typical slapping thing that I got from Larry Graham.
Oh, that's cool.
All right.
Let me go to another one then, tapping.
Is that different?
Tapping is sort of like what a piano player does.
Most of the time on a stringed instrument like a guitar, I have to use two hands to produce one note.
My right hand has to pluck the string.
My left hand has to fret the finger board, meaning master string down somewhere along the neck.
But when I'm tapping, I can just play a note with one hand.
So in other words, if I go to the twelfth fret with my left hand and just like I'm either playing a piano or tapping on a typewriter, I just mash the string down with one hand.
That leaves my right hand free, and so I can do tapping with both hands, and then I can play the bass sort of like a piano.
(Soundbite of music)
That's tapping.
Let's go to them three-finger plucking.
I think that was the banjo, you know.
It is exactly.
You nailed it.
It's like a banjo.
When I first met one of the greatest banjos ever, Bela Fleck, I handed him my bass and I said, please play this like a banjo.
And he uses three fingers at all the times on his picking hand, which is his right hand.
He uses his thumb and his index and middle, right.
Now, you could use your ring finger and your pinkie if you want.

But when I was doing Larry Graham's technique a minute ago, I would pluck with one finger, but I could also pluck with two fingers and get kind of a rapid-fire thing, like a (makes sounds) instead of one.
Now, my brother, Reggie, when I was very young, showed me how to use my thumb in two directions, downwards and upwards.
So I can now go down with my thumb and then come up with my thumb, and it'll sound like a pluck.
Right, so I can pluck the low strings with my thumb.
As soon as I pluck the low string with my thumb, I can pluck a high string with my index finger twice.
So...
(Soundbite of music)
Right, so now when I'm playing like the same Larry Graham, I can get these two.
(Soundbite of music)
All sorts of sounds.
Nice.
Yeah.
You were also talking about learning from the kids and teaching the kids.
You brought some kids with you, I think, to demonstrate.
Yeah, yeah.
Should we have them do something here?
I think so, yeah.
When I was young, like you said, I got a chance to actually tour when I was my kids' age, and I have four kids, and three of them are here.
I have a 12-year-old, Kyla(ph), who is going to sing for us, and, oh, I've got to actually change basses while I'm talking.
